question: Question_08_(a)
statement:
Let $y = (ax + b)^7$, where \emph{a} and \emph{b} are constant.

(a) Suppose that \emph{a ≠ 0}. Find the equation of the line tangent to
the curve at

\[x = \frac{b}{a}.\]
sols:
If \emph{a} is different than zero, then the given curve is a polynomial
of degree 7. Let

\[\displaystyle
f(x) = (ax+b)^7\] then its derivative (using the chain rule) is

\[\displaystyle
f'(x) = 7(ax+b)^6 \cdot a = 7a(ax+b)^6\] and so the slope of the tangent
line to this curve at the point \emph{x} = \emph{b}/\emph{a} is

\[\displaystyle
f'(b/a) = 7a(a \left( \frac{b}{a} \right) +b)^6 = 7a(2b)^6 = 2^6 \cdot 7 a b^6\]
And the \emph{y} coordinate of that point is $f(b/a)$ which is

\[\displaystyle
f(b/a) = (a \left( \frac{b}{a} \right) +b)^7 = (2b)^7 = 2^7b^7\] So
using the standard equation

\[\displaystyle
y=m(x-x_0)+y_0\] for a line of slope \emph{m} and going through the
point (\emph{x}\textsubscript{0}, \emph{y}\textsubscript{0}) we obtain

\[\displaystyle
y=2^6 \cdot 7 a b^6 (x-\frac{b}{a}) + 2^7b^7\] which you can simplify a
bit and obtain

\[\displaystyle
y=2^6 \cdot 7 a b^6 x - 2^6 \cdot 5 b^7\] or if you compute things out

\[\displaystyle
y=448 a b^6 x - 320 b^7\] You don't need to do the last two steps during
a test usually.
hints:
If it looks like keeping track of a lot of symbols and having an answer
that will depend on both \emph{a} and \emph{b}, then you are on the
right track.
